I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the strengthening of 
fiscal, debt, and public financial management (PFM) in Papua New Guinea (PNG) to mitigate 
fiscal and debt sustainability risks, which have been aggravated by the coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) pandemic. The TA builds upon existing support of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
for PFM in PNG, including for health sector reforms, PFM reform, and fiscal management.1 It will 
provide (i) policy assessments on PFM issues to inform government planning; and (ii) support for 
capacity development in public sector management in prioritized areas. 
 
2.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  ADB's  Strategy  2030  operational  priority  6  (strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity).2 It also reflects ADB’s country partnership strategy for 
PNG, 2021–2025, Strategic Pathway 2 priority areas of improving fiscal, debt, and PFM, and 
responding to shocks.3 The TA is included in the country operations business plan for PNG, 2021–
2023.4 It also aligns with the Government of Papua New Guinea’s PFM reform agenda and 
country development plans.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Development and economic context. PNG is a lower middle-income country, classified 
as a fragile and conflict-affected situation, that faces significant development challenges, including 
institutional weaknesses and capacity constraints.6 Annual gross domestic product (GDP) growth 
averaged only 2.1% from 2016 to 2020, dragged down by a series of shocks that included a 
decline in commodity prices, a severe drought, and a major earthquake.7 The COVID-19 crisis 
resulted in an estimated 3.3% contraction in the GDP in 2020. A significant 37.5% of the 
population lives below the national poverty line.8 Gender equality remains a challenge and women 
have substantially less access to health care and education services than men.9 
 
4.  Public sector management. The public sector plays a key role in helping government 
manage macroeconomic risks and improve development outcomes. However, fiscal outcomes 
have  generally  been  poor,  symptomatic  of  capacity  constraints  in  fiscal  management  and 
vulnerability to exogenous shocks. PNG’s budget deficit averaged 4.7% from 2016 to 2020.

Revenues have weakened alongside economic challenges.10 The tax to GDP ratio averaged only 
12.7%  during  2016–2020,  below  the  15%  benchmark  generally  regarded  as  the  minimum 
required for sustainable development.11 At the same time, expenditure composition has worsened 
as recurrent expenditures, especially the public sector wage bill, have continued to rise and 
overrun budget estimates. The 2020 International Monetary Fund (IMF) Staff-Monitored Program 
has helped direct reform priorities.12 
 
5.  Weak fiscal management. Fiscal management is guided by a comprehensive medium-
term fiscal strategy (MTFS) and the Fiscal Responsibility Act (FRA).13 However, both the MTFS 
and FRA have been subject to frequent revisions since 2016, contributing to weaker fiscal 
outcomes.14 There is a need to strengthen medium-term, policy-based budgeting given the 
frequency of shocks and the continued fiscal difficulties that are expected to affect PNG post-
pandemic. The government will also need support in adhering to fiscal strategies and fiscal rules 
and improving the content and coverage of budget documents. In turn, this will require stronger 
macroeconomic  forecasting  and  improved  budget  reliability.  ADB  has  been  supporting  the 
government in many of these areas, but more support is needed.15 Because budgets can be a 
tool for supporting gender equality and raising awareness of how budgets affect different groups 
of people, the government also requires assistance in gender-responsive budgeting and gender 
analysis of the budget.16 
 
6.  Debt management vulnerabilities. The increase in public debt since 2020, driven by the 
COVID-19 pandemic has reemphasized the need for prudent debt management. Public debt 
increased from 33.7% of GDP in 2016 to 49.2% in 2020. In June 2020, an updated IMF debt 
sustainability analysis indicated that PNG faces a high risk of debt distress.17 The government 
has revised its medium-term debt strategy, focusing on concessional financing and decreasing 
the government's reliance on short-term domestic borrowing with the aim of reducing the public 
debt-to-GDP ratio to under 40%.18 Debt management capacities also need to be enhanced to 
address shortcomings flagged in various assessments, including (i) insufficient monitoring and

reporting on public debt liabilities and insufficient and incomplete data accuracy, impacted by 
PNG’s existing debt management system;19 (ii) insufficient debt management guidelines, weak 
operational risk management, and staffing issues; and (iii) gaps in analytical capacity that impede 
effective management of debt vulnerabilities.20 ADB has been supporting debt management and 
the government has indicated that they would like this support to continue.21 
 
7.  Inadequate controls on budget execution. Progress has been made in PFM in PNG, 
guided by the 2015 Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA) road map.22 Notable 
reform success include improvements made in the PFM legal framework, and accelerated rollout 
of an integrated financial management system. From 2019 to 2020, a new PEFA assessment was 
completed, and a PFM road map exercise commenced, which is being finalized and will guide 
further reform efforts.23 Despite some progress, weaknesses remain in procurement processes, 
payroll audit, and responsiveness to internal audit recommendations.24 Of notable concern are 
deficiencies in public accounts preparation across various levels of government and for statutory 
authorities, which affect the successful preparation of PNG’s national accounts. Public financial 
information is frequently unaudited, incomplete, not easily available, or significantly delayed. 
 
8.  Lessons learned and development partner coordination. Key lessons for ADB include 
the need to (i) deliver sustained support and engagement with the Department of Treasury (DOT), 
Department of Finance, and other government departments on PFM reforms; (ii) build capacity 
not just for government counterparts, but also for key decision makers; (iii) maintain sustained 
communication with the government and development partners on the reform agenda; and (iv) 
maintain flexibility to respond to evolving issues and needs. ADB will take into account support 
being provided by other bilateral and multilateral development partners who are engaged in PFM 
reforms, including the European Union, the IMF and its Pacific Financial Technical Assistance 
Centre, the World Bank, and the governments of Australia, Japan, and New Zealand.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: prudent management of fiscal policy and 
budget discipline attained.25 The TA will have the following outcome: PFM strengthened.26

B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Advice on enhancing fiscal management provided. The TA will support the 
government  in  strengthening  fiscal  and  economic  management  through  high-quality  policy 
dialogue and capacity building. It will produce briefing notes, analytical reports, and background 
information that can be incorporated into decision-making and policy dialogue. The TA will 
conduct training workshops to help build capacity in identified areas. Experts will work closely with 
DOT counterparts, but may also support other government departments.27 Areas for support will 
be  developed  in  consultation  with  the  government  and  are  expected  to  evolve  over  the 
implementation period. Initially, the TA will cover support for (i) the review and update of fiscal, 
revenue, and expenditure strategies; (ii) review of the MTFS and FRA, and drafting of other fiscal 
legislation;  (iii)  drafting  and  review  of  key  budget  documents;  
(iv) improved budgeting techniques and macroeconomic and fiscal forecasting; and (v) gender-
responsive budgeting. 28 Policy advice will incorporate gender considerations wherever feasible. 
Women will comprise at least 30% of trainees and/or attendees in capacity building workshops 
and events. 
 
11.  Output 2: Improved debt management supported. The TA will support stronger debt 
management through policy advice and technical support for the DOT. The initial scope of work 
identified with the government is support for (i) increased transparency, debt data accuracy, and 
debt data completeness, including smooth migration from the current debt recording system to its 
proposed  successor;  (ii)  enhanced  analytical  capacity  of  DOT  staff  for  managing  debt 
vulnerabilities and risks; (iii) development of an updated medium-term public debt strategy for 
2023–2027; and (iv) improved communication on debt and more timely availability of debt data, 
including the creation of an annual public debt bulletin. 
 
12.  Output  3:  Support  for  strengthening  budget  execution  controls  provided.  In 
accordance with the forthcoming PEFA assessment, the TA will support capacity building of the 
Auditor General’s Office to (i) improve the quality and increase the quantity of financial reporting 
outputs, including for public accounts and statutory authorities; (ii) meet reporting responsibilities, 
which will be backed up by an assessment on the backlog of audits and a plan to address delays; 
(iii) follow up on audit findings; and (iv) support an update of the Audit Manual, which will clearly 
detail responsibilities, timelines, and procedures to follow. At a later stage, the TA will explore 
providing training to government agencies, public corporations, and provincial entities to improve 
financial reporting. The TA will also support the government in reforming its procurement function 
through strengthening procurement monitoring, methods, public access to information, and other 
priorities identified in the PEFA road map (forthcoming). 
 
13.  Areas of support are expected to evolve over the TA implementation period. TA outputs 
will be delivered by international and national consultants, working closely with government 
counterparts and ADB. The experts will deliver a mix of capacity building support involving 
workshops, group discussions, and on-the-job training. To be effective, consultants will need to 
work alongside government counterparts in PNG.29 The delivery method builds on lessons from 
previous ADB policy-based operations and TA that supported PFM (footnote 1).  
 
27 Other government departments may include the Department of Planning, the Department of Finance, and the Prime 
Minister’s Office. 
28 The TA will provide flexible assistance for strengthening domestic resource mobilization and complement support 
provided by the IMF and ADB’s Asia Pacific Tax Hub.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
2. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, office space, office 
supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB, through its Pacific Department, will administer the knowledge and support TA over 
a 5-year period, from January 2022 to December 2026. Implementation will be harmonized with 
ADB’s other activities in PNG through the resident mission and will be coordinated with ADB 
departments such as the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department and the 
Procurement, Portfolio, and Financial Management Department. The indicative implementation 
arrangements are summarized in the table below.

16.  Consulting services. A total of 108 person-months of inputs are envisaged over a 60-
month period, including 88 person-months of individual international consultants, on a continuous 
or intermittent basis, and 20 person-months of individual national consultants. The specific 
requirements of expertise and length of engagement will depend on the scope of work to be 
determined during TA implementation.30 Consultants will be required to submit 6 monthly reports 
detailing progress on their specific outputs. Evaluation of their performance will be based on 
assessments by ADB and the government. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Papua  New  Guinea  for  Strengthening  Fiscal,  Debt,  and  Financial 
Management, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
